title: Asynchronous Video Exchange
synopsis: Working with live distributed events and video does not necessarily involve live streaming content from one space to another. Indeed live streaming into a physical conference event is nearly always a disappointment.

title: Berlin
synopsis: <UL><LI>

title: Bio-Commons
synopsis: In this whitepaper the results of the scenario thinking workshop and brainstorm discussions on the topic of the [[Bio-Commons]] are presented. As a way to realize these concepts, a hypothetical licensing model termed [[Bio-Commons]] (in analogy to the [[Creative Commons]]) was discussed.

title: Bio Commons Lab
synopsis: The Lab consists of 6 days of unconferences, workshops and biohacking , where we where we will build together the [[Bio-Commons]] - [http://www.commons.camp/bio-commons-lab/ commons.camp]

title: Centre Culturel des Cèdres
synopsis: [[Centre Culturel des Cèdres]] - [http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/64742753#map=16/43.6182/6.9732 openstreetmap]

synopsis: Here we list [[Recent Changes]] to [[Fedwiki Sites]]:

title: Changes to the Commons
synopsis: Here we list [[Recent Changes]] to [[Commons Sites]]:

title: Changes to this Site
synopsis: Below we list recent changes to this site only without also listing changes from the [[Neighbourhood]]:

title: Chaos Computer Camp
synopsis: This page is redirected here:

title: Common People
synopsis: Here we write about the [[Common People]], that is people who have in one way or other substantially added to the [[commons]], or are writing here together.

title: Commons
synopsis: [[The commons]] is the cultural and natural resources accessible to all members of a society, including natural materials such as air, water, and a habitable earth. These resources are held in common, not owned privately - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commons wikipedia]

title: Commons Academy
synopsis: The Commons Academy is a place to learn about the [[Commons]], [[Creating a Commons]], and the [[Stewardship of the Commons]].

title: Commons Camp
synopsis: The Commons Camp is a summer Camp meant to understand and discuss about possible transformations of the present. Merging of theory and practice: we feel the urgency to foster the transition towards collaborative economies, in order to build a more resilient society.

title: Commons Reading List
synopsis: Here we list some reading related to concept and theory of [[the commons]]. Tick each article off as you read them. You may wish to add to this list here (on your forked copy), or over at Wikipedia - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commons#References wikipedia]

title: Commons Sites
synopsis: Here we list a number of sites and resources about the various forms of the commons. This page helps us track [[Changes to the Commons]]:

title: Corporate Toxics Information Project
synopsis: PERI’s Corporate Toxics Information Project develops and disseminates information and analysis on corporate releases of pollutants and the consequences for communities - [http://www.peri.umass.edu/ctip_research/ umass.edu]

title: Credit Commons
synopsis: Credit Commons is a proposal by [[Matthew Slater]] to reform the way finance and [[The Commons]].

title: Cultural Commons
synopsis: Today, the commons are also understood within a [[cultural]] sphere. These commons include literature, music, arts, design, film, video, television, radio, information, software and sites of heritage. [[Wikipedia]] is an example of the production and maintenance of [[Common Good]]s by a contributor community in the form of encyclopedic knowledge that can be freely accessed by anyone without a central authority.

title: Currently Working On
synopsis: Here is a list of [[Recent Changes]] I consider important. View our experiments on the [[Scratch]] page. To clear stuff saved in your browser try [[Local Changes]].

title: Distributed Unconference
synopsis: We need to be able to hold rich distributed conversations. This is both a core part of the process of deliberation in the [[Parliament of Things]], and a bootstrapping process in order to enable us to design the tools and techniques that we need to support the construction of this new democracy. It is a pressing question of practice, not merely theory - [http://www.parliamentofthings.org/thing/distributed-unconferences/ parliamentofthings.org]

title: Events
synopsis: As part of the [[Commons Academy]] we are organising a series of events, leading up to a [[Celebration of the Commons]] that will take place in [[Spring 2016]].

title: Expired Domains
synopsis: Here are some domains I've let expire. There is content there so I'll move them over to the new site.

title: Fedwiki Tools
synopsis: Here we list a few tools that are of particular use in managing and creating [[Fedwiki]] content.

title: Greenhouse 100
synopsis: PERI's Greenhouse 100 index identifies the top companies responsible for greenhouse gas emissions - [http://www.peri.umass.edu/greenhouse/ umass.edu]

title: Knowledge Commons
synopsis: Elinor Ostrom, with Oliver Williamson, won the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences in 2009 because she demonstrated that regular folks like you and I can create and self-govern a commons in a sustainable and equitable manner - [http://www.elinorostrom.com elinorostrom.com]

title: La Médiathèque de Mouans-Sartoux
synopsis: La Médiathèque seems to be the space that organised the Minecraft project [http://www.lamediatheque.net/ lamediatheque.net]

title: Make Commoning Work
synopsis: # A Framework for Understanding Commons & Commoning

title: Mouans-Sartoux
synopsis: From the 11th to 15th of June,  will gather in Mouans-Sartoux to facilitate workshops, teardowns, co-design and prototyping sessions.

title: Next Edge Festival
synopsis: This independent event is scheduled to take part at the same time as [[OSCEDays]] (it finishes one day earlier).

title: Open data
synopsis: Open data is the idea that some data should be freely available to everyone to use and republish as they wish, without restrictions from copyright, patents or other mechanisms of control - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_data wikipedia]

title: OpenStreetMap
synopsis: OpenStreetMap (OSM) is a collaborative project to create a free editable map of the world. Two major driving forces behind the establishment and growth of OSM have been restrictions on use or availability of map information across much of the world and the advent of inexpensive portable satellite navigation devices. OSM is considered a prominent example of volunteered geographic information - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Openstreetmap wikipedia]

title: OSCEdays
synopsis: A global distributed event (JUNE 11th – 15th, 2015), exploring the [[Open Source]] and the [[Circular Economy]] - [https://oscedays.org/ oscedays.org]

title: Our First Party
synopsis: Our first party is going to be at [[Chaos Computer Camp]].

title: Permaculture
synopsis: Permaculture is a system of agricultural and social design principles centered on simulating or directly utilizing the patterns and features observed in natural ecosystems.

title: PLAST
synopsis: Pattern Languages for Systemic Change (PLAST) was initially created under [[Next Edge]] Agency Catalyst Workgroup, to explore the notion of human agency and how we as change activists could help unleash, cultivate and maximize human agency to bring about transformative change - [https://www.facebook.com/groups/125513674232534/permalink/757873457663216/ facebook]

title: Radio
synopsis: Radio is the technology of using radio waves to carry information, such as sound, by systematically modulating properties of electromagnetic energy waves transmitted through space, such as their amplitude, frequency, phase, or pulse width. When radio waves strike an electrical conductor, the oscillating fields induce an alternating current in the conductor. The information in the waves can be extracted and transformed back into its original form - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio wikipedia]

title: Stockhom
synopsis: What potential does Open source have to transit us to a circular economy? How would our production waste change? What structures do we need to create to make a circular economy work? How could allocation of resources be determined in a circular economy?

title: The Commons
synopsis: The [[Commons]] is the cultural and natural resources accessible to all members of a society, including natural materials such as air, water, and a habitable earth. These resources are held in common, not owned privately - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commons wikipedia]

title: Toxic 100
synopsis: A list of the top 100 polluters - [http://www.peri.umass.edu/fileadmin/pdf/dpe/ctip/justice_in_the_air.pdf Justice in the Air]

title: Évaléco
synopsis: Evaléco

title: Varambon
synopsis: Hosting OSCE day in Varambon, a small village near the river of Ain is a challenge in and of itself: The idea is to get inspired and build upon collective work methodology from city based communities (lots of student, creatives, public transport, etc..) and FORK it, in a rural setting.

title: Welcome Visitors
synopsis: Here we write about the [[World of the Commons]]. Follow [[Changes to this Site]] or [[Changes to the Commons]] to find out what we are [[Currently Working On]].

title: World-Making in a Pluriverse
synopsis: A commons is a process of "world-making". It brings an individual into focused, ongoing collaborations that in effect build a rich, shared, subjective and distinct "world." This world is not a universe but a pluriverse. A world where many worlds fit, to quote the [[Zapatistas]], [http://www.caferebelion.com/declaration.html html].

title: World of the Commons
synopsis: The [[Commons]] is not a singular thing. There are many diverse forms of commons. Here we collect them together so that they can learn from and inform each other.
